question: For the reaction, <katex>$A \rightleftharpoons B$</katex> <katex>$E_{a}=50 \ kJ \ mol^{-1}$</katex> and <katex>$\Delta H=-20 \ kJ \ mol^{-1}$</katex>. When a catalyst is added, <katex>$E_{a}$</katex> decreases by <katex>$10 \ kJ \ mol^{-1}$</katex>. What is the <katex>$E_{a}$</katex> for the backward reaction in the presence of catalyst?
explanation: For uncatalyzed: <katex>$\Delta H = E_{a(f)} - E_{a(b)}$</katex>, so <katex>$-20 = 50 - E_{a(b)} \Rightarrow E_{a(b)} = 70$</katex>. Catalyst lowers activation energy by 10. New <katex>$E_{a(b)}' = 70 - 10 = 60 \ kJ \ mol^{-1}$</katex>.
